medical_history.chief_complaint: Respiratory distress in a male newborn delivered at 31 weeks and 4 days of gestation.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The newborn presented with limp tone and poor respiratory effort immediately after birth and was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit due to respiratory distress. The condition worsened, requiring intubation at 7 hours after birth due to increased dyspnea, hypotonia, decreased responsiveness, and decreased blood pressure. He underwent two failed extubation attempts until 21 days after birth. At 36 weeks postmenstrual age (PMA), he was still dependent on non-invasive intermittent positive pressure ventilation. He experienced two episodes of pneumonia. At 44 weeks and 4 days PMA, the infant was discharged from the hospital with oxygen therapy and partial nasal feeding.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Prenatal ultrasound revealed ventricular widening and polyhydramnios. The newborn's mother developed hypertension during pregnancy.
